event.doc_name: Class Action Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

extracted.value: Josephine County's Point-in-Time Count identified 1,754 homeless or at-risk individuals (654 on streets, 1,011 precariously housed) in Grants Pass as of 2017.

evidence.text: the Point-in-Time Count of homeless people in Josephine County found 654 individuals on the street and another 1011 individuals precariously housed for a total of 1754 people who are homeless or at immediate risk of homelessness.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

patch.value: Gospel Rescue Mission shelters have limited capacity (30 beds for single men, 4 for single women, 12 for mothers with children) and restrictive rules, including prohibitions on medical issues, nicotine, and certain relationships.

evidence.text: “If you have serious or chronic medical or mental issues that prevent you from participating in daily Mission life, you may not be able to stay at the Mission.” “Medications must be turned in at the front desk.” “You are to remain nicotine free during your stay at the Mission.” “There is no socializing between members of the opposite sex except at approved Mission events. Treat one another as a brother and/or sister. All intimate relationships other than legal/biblical marriage, regardless of gender, either on or off Mission property are strictly forbidden.” “Taking a sick day will result in losing pass privileges for 72 hours and confinement to staying indoors during this time to insure a thorough recovery from illness.” “Every Sunday, you are required to attend a church approved by the Mission staff. The individual church is your choice, however it must hold to traditional Christian teachings such as the Apostles Creed.”
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

patch.value: Debra Blake received multiple citations for sleeping/camping violations (July 1, 2014; Sept 24, 2014; Oct 4, 2014; Oct 28, 2015; May 1, 2016; July 17, 2018), totaling over $4,000 in fines.

evidence.text: On July 1, 2014, at 6:20 a.m., Ms. Blake was cited for violating GPMC 5.61.020 for sleeping in an alley at 620 SE J Street in Grants Pass and was fined $35. ... Ms. Blake is unable to pay this fine, which because of late fees is now $109. ... On July 17, 2018, Ms. Blake was sleeping in Riverside Park in Grants Pass at 7:33 a.m. ... Her fine for this offense is now $410. ... Ms. Blake now owes the City of Grants Pass more than $4000 in fines for crimes and violations related directly to her involuntary homelessness.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

patch.value: Grants Pass removed park benches, built fences around bus stop benches, and offered one-way bus fare to encourage homeless people to leave town.

evidence.text: The City has removed park benches from its parks so that people have no place in public to rest. The City has built fences around bus stop benches. City police have offered to pay one-way bus fare to get homeless people out of town.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

patch.value: Grants Pass Municipal Code ordinances (GPMC 5.61.020, 5.61.030, 6.46.090) criminalize sleeping, camping, and resting in public spaces without providing legal shelter options.

evidence.text: 5.61.020 Sleeping on Sidewalks, Streets, Alleys, or Within Doorways Prohibited ... A. No person may sleep on public sidewalks, streets, or alleyways at any time as a matter of individual and public safety. ... 5.61.030 Camping Prohibited ... No person may occupy a campsite in or upon any sidewalk, street, alley, lane, public right of way, park, bench, or any other publicly-owned property or under any bridge or viaduct, ... 6.46.090 Camping in Parks ... A. It is unlawful for any person to camp within the boundaries of a City Park. ...
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

patch.value: Grants Pass selectively enforced anti-camping/sleeping ordinances against homeless individuals; 208 tickets reviewed (2015-2017) showed 67/83 camping tickets and 93/125 sleeping tickets were officer-initiated.

evidence.text: Counsel for plaintiffs reviewed dozens of anti-camping and anti-sleeping citations produced to them by Defendants pursuant to a public records request. These tickets were issued between January of 2015 and May of 2017. Of the 208 tickets received and reviewed, almost all of them were issued to people who were homeless at the time of issuance. These tickets show that these ordianances are selectively enforced against homeless individuals. Also, the tickets were usually issued based on officer initiated patrols, not based upon complaints from the public. Of the 83 camping tickets issued pursuant to GPMC 5.61.030, 67 were officer initiated. Of the 125 sleeping tickets issued pursuant to GPMC 5.61.020, 93 of them were officer initiated.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

extracted.value: Point-in-Time count shows 1754 homeless or at immediate risk of homelessness (654 on streets, 1011 precariously housed).

evidence.text: The most recent “point in time” count in Josephine County found 654 individuals on the street and another 1011 individuals precariously housed for a total of 1754 people who are homeless or at immediate risk of homelessness.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

patch.value: Grants Pass has severe affordable housing shortage with no low-barrier emergency shelter for homeless people.

evidence.text: Grants Pass is in the midst of an affordable housing crisis. There is not nearly enough affordable housing to house all of the low-income residents of Grants Pass. ... Grants Pass has no low-barrier emergency shelter for homeless individuals.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

patch.value: City removed park benches and offered one-way bus fare to drive homeless people out of town.

evidence.text: The City has removed park benches from its parks. The City has paid one-way bus fare for homeless people to leave town.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

patch.value: Plaintiff Debra Blake received multiple citations for sleeping/camping violations including $4000+ in fines.

evidence.text: On July 1, 2014, at 6:20 a.m., Ms. Blake was cited for violating GPMC 5.61.020 for sleeping in an alley... fine $35 (now $109). ... On July 17, 2018, Ms. Blake was cited for camping in park... fine $410. Ms. Blake now owes the City of Grants Pass more than $4000 in fines.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

patch.value: City selectively enforces anti-camping/sleeping ordinances against homeless individuals without public complaints.

evidence.text: Counsel for plaintiffs reviewed dozens of anti-camping and anti-sleeping citations... Of the 208 tickets... almost all were issued to homeless people. Of the 83 camping tickets... 67 were officer initiated. Of the 125 sleeping tickets... 93 were officer initiated.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

patch.value: Relevant ordinances include GPMC 5.61.020 (sleeping prohibited), 5.61.030 (camping prohibited), and 6.46.090 (camping in parks).

evidence.text: City of Grants Pass Municipal Code 5.61.020 Sleeping on Sidewalks, Streets, Alleys, or Within Doorways Prohibited... 5.61.030 Camping Prohibited... 6.46.090 Camping in Parks
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

evidence.text: Unlike other comparably sized cities in Oregon, Grants Pass has no low-barrier emergency shelter for homeless individuals. There is no place in Grants Pass where people can simply show up and receive shelter during the day or night.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief
